inhoud: Exploring ways to procreate through objects rather than biology. Do we still need to rely on biology to secure our continued existence? Mass media already extends our influence far beyond the physical, so why not take this a step further? Anh does this in a new survival strategy that challenges the idea of reproduction and the individual. With mass-produced objects that can be easily replicated, Ahn aims to spread his identity far and wide. How? By releasing 3,000 balloons of his face and dragging a plaster portrait of himself across the street. With a bed built from copies of his head he even invades the act of conception itself.

A shelving unit and lamp is covered by a thin membrane that reveals the inner structure at work. In objects and architecture, the inner anatomy is often concealed behind façades and casings. Inspired by our own bodies, Alex Blondeau explores how skin and skeleton can work together. By making this relationship visible, the resulting design reveals a more complete picture. A structure of moveable parts is covered by a balloon-like membrane. When the air is sucked out, the outer skin is pulled taut. The skin shapes the structure − or does the structure shape the skin?

Devices for a ‘sonic recalibration lab’ that help us re-engage with the sounds around us, so we are better able to deal with them. The birth of the Industrial Revolution and the resulting machines and devices spawned a whole soundscape of what we currently classify as noise. Colette Aliman calls this the ‘Mechaphony’. We use decibels to measure sound, but the focus is only on one aspect: the noise level. This creates an inherent negative bias in our perception. Two ceramic interfaces access the Mechaphony database, transforming the sounds and our relationship to them to create a more positive response to our daily aural input.

titel: ‘Soon All This Will Be Picturesque Ruins’
inhoud: This project tackles narratives that respond to issues of gentrification and the diminishing presence of queer space in cities. A tension between creation and destruction seems for some to be a necessary part of urban development. But in reality, it can play out as a violent process of exclusion of those that occupied the space before. The installation documents a series of immersive performances which took place within a disused shed at a property in Eindhoven, soon to be redeveloped. After each of the four acts, the interior was fully renovated into a new spatial design, tracking different archetypal clichés associated with gentrification. Starting as a gay bar, the shed was transformed into a café, an Airbnb and a luxury property marketing event.

The Beauty of Distortion’ is a study on how our prejudices about materials can be altered through subversive use of crafting techniques, resulting in a series of elegant plastic objects. Today, plastic increasingly has a negative connotation. The material has permeated all uses, and with its ubiquitous proliferation it finally ended up having a disgraceful reputationIs it possible to shift perspectives towards a new understanding of what this material could evoke? Blowing and melting plastic as if it were glass makes you see plastic as you see glass. The resulting objects bring about a new notion of beauty, one that is alluringly twisted, warped and bent instead of being industrially dull.

A range of furniture to investigate our appreciation of antique objects. The revision of classical pieces with contemporary ornamentation contrasts conservative beauty with contemporary scenes considered more banal. Antique objects appear to have a firmly established sense of beauty, expressing a certain wealth and an idealised past. Replicas, however lack that charm, and are quickly seen as kitsch. What defines the difference? Instead of classic representations, this furniture is adorned with everyday scenes of decay that we normally might ignore, disdain or consider as banal. When aestheticised in this format that refers to the past, they suddenly lose their deceptive character and become a commentary on our contemporary society.

This project takes the industrial method of extruding pasta and translates it into the world of 3D software, breathing new life into a stagnant tradition. In the global imagination, Italy means pasta and vice versa. The cliché transforms the country’s eating habits into the main characteristic of the people, fuelling the stereotype of Italian identity. How can design be used to question such deep-rooted conventions? How can 3D modelling, rapid prototyping and new materials connect to a national heritage in which food, industry, and politics have a complex relationship? Gianmaria Della Ratta took the extrusion method and generated rules for efficiency, form, scale and process, some based on traditional pasta shapes. Unlike traditional production, extrusion always leads to different results.

A search for a more honest aesthetic for technological devices we commonly trust blindly, such as an ATMWe tend to have complete faith in products that look neutral and simple. Yet modernist design can be misleading, since functional appearance is a designed aesthetic too. Can we still have confidence in designed objects, Gijs de Boer asks, when we can detect that their neutrality is a mask? Inspired by sampling and citing methods from pop culture, Gijs copies a seemingly neutral ATM incompletely, leaving clues to reveal its modernist mask. ‘Probably an ATM’ tests if you can trust an honest façade.

titel: Wearing Chairs While Sitting On Pants
inhoud: A synthesis of furniture and clothing to go beyond the original features of each. Furniture and clothing are seen as two separate things. But they don’t have to be. Both facilitate the body in its environment. Fueled by his own passion for clothing, Hansol Kim questions the strict boundary between the two and aims to create a new kind of object in the space between these categories. Evocative sculptures use and juxtapose existing forms, functions and materials, such as leather, that are common to furniture as well as clothing. They present a new hybrid form to excite and intrigue.

Sculpting a new path towards adaptable design. With industrial modelling clay, a common tool in car design, Johanna Seelemann creates a series of abstract products that can be continually restyled by the user. An accompanying book brings together narratives on the evolution of aesthetics. What role does appearance play in determining a product’s survival? In an age of sustainability and climate crisis, mass sectors such as the car industry and fashion remain entrenched in patterns where aesthetics remains a dominant force in design. For Johanna, this non-rational focus on the way things look drives modern over-consumption. In collaboration with Adriana Pacheco and car designer Daniel Rauch.

An exploration of the relationship between real and unreal through a deep-sea organism.  Today, we experience a version of nature that is manicured, virtual, and artificial. The internet provides a ubiquitous matrix, in a parallel reality of real nature. The technological perspective on nature is always flattened, abstracted, altered through layers of machine interpretation. According to Kurina Sohn, the relationship between representation, creation and life can no longer be divided between real and unreal. As a result, the boundaries between nature, imagery, machine and body blur.  Kurina reconstructed a crinoid (or ‘sea lily’) in the form of a kinetic structure that mimics natural behaviour. Also, using digitized fossil records, she used a syringe to pump air into the soft robotics and resin-print object.

A hosted experience that triggers our perception of the everyday through cyclical processes of interaction between objects and participants. Our daily routines are embedded in cycles: the natural ones we are forced to live by, and those we create for ourselves. These repetitive cycles make us perform actions thoughtlessly because they have become so ingrained in our behaviour. The everyday becomes part of our character. Marie Rime brings this invisible system of cycles and their traces to light in a performative installation. Her handmade objects and the parameters she sets make participants aware of their freedom and possibilities in our perceived restraint.

titel: Bend the Rules, Stretch the Norm
inhoud: Who owns the public space? This project explores that question with small interventions in the streets of Rotterdam. In a city that is getting more regulated every day, Maurik Stomps playfully stretches the norm by appropriating small pieces of public space. His unrideable bike, welded from two back halves, was tolerated for three weeks, and his sinkhole-proof tiles with an opening for rats only a few days. Stretching it further, he built a house on a bike and left it unattended. When three people started to live there, all seemed fine; Maurik even started to improve his design. But when his guests changed things to their own taste, the authorities stepped in and the system of ‘normalisation’ was set in motion.

A dinner setting for one person, featuring a table and chair, to show how memories are encapsulated in physical objects. Starting with a big table and four chairs, Micheline Nahra deconstructed these objects into their constituent parts and used them to construct a table and chair for one person. Raised in war-torn Lebanon, Micheline is well aware of the fragility of our surroundings. Everything can be lost at any time. For her, deconstructing and reconstructing is a way of exploring the relationship between objects and the layering of stories in them. Her pieces reflect the human need to retrace the past and preserve memories.

titel: Sun, don’t rush to be red – 11 films
inhoud: What questions are asked without the presumption of an answer? Why do we need to answer these questions? How to answer a question without giving an answer?

Welcome to Stream City, the fictional flying city that explores an alternative vision for a transient way of living. Spending time among the clouds living as a flying nomad forces you to let go of belongings, places, and even people, embracing a freer, more ephemeral existence. The experience can inspire us to be less bound to our set values upon our return to the everyday world. Stéphane has designed conceptual electromagnetic gauntlets and flying suits for his futuristic urban experience. Soar and swoop through Stream City, with its network of floating infrastructures, on an audio tour with a VR headset. A film documents users’ imagined experiences.

A coffee machine that amplifies the experience of wastefulness by making a ceramic cup disposable. Consumerism tends to be viewed as an attachment to material goods, perpetuating a desire for more and more. Tobias Bridger thinks the opposite: a disvalue of material makes it easier for us to thoughtlessly replace the old with the new. Tobias believes we should actually become more materialistic through a greater attachment to material, allowing us to be more conscious of our actions towards disposal and thereby less wasteful. A ceramic cup is predominantly seen as stable. Making the cup disposable reveals the irrationality of recycling when posed as a conclusive solution to our wastefulness.

titel: I Look at a Thing and What Do I See?
inhoud: An exploration of what happens if machine-learning algorithms are trained to become subjective. An object is never just an isolated entity. It is connected to a context, memory or feeling. This is what gives things meaning. But how to teach meaning to algorithms that are being developed to look upon our world with an automated gaze? Vera van der Burg trained a speculative algorithm with datasets of her emotions. Scanning a still life of ambiguous objects that she created, the algorithm interprets their emotional content. Unlike vanitas paintings, which remind us of life’s meaninglessness, the scene through the eye of the machine reminds us of our desire to find meaning.

A collection of objects with blurry and fluid boundaries. All original boundaries are hidden under soft textiles. We all have different boundaries in dealing with different people, also depending on the cultural context. We need continuous communication to discover our boundaries. In her work Yanjin Wu transposes this this state of undefined boundaries to objects as a metaphor. Their hidden shape and function requires the same exploration as is needed to discover the boundaries between two humans. The public will have to explore the objects that are covered in textiles by touching them. The interaction with these objects allows people to create their own functions and context for the objects.

A setting for curating events that explore the notion of love. The forms of encounter and action provoked in turn affect and diffract the space. Reading or hearing the word ‘love’ triggers all sorts of demands and hopes to connect with others. Esteban Gomez Rosselli curated a ‘diagrammatic space’ to test the capacity of dialogue to foster a dynamic understanding of this ambivalent topic. A series of performative lectures held in the installation take love as a dynamic prop. The events draw attention to the concept, the word itself working as a screen upon which participants project their own experiences and interpretations.

Investigating the paradox of the museum as both repository and producer of knowledge. The popular image of Greek statues is rendered in iconic white marble — even though they were colourful. Why is this myth so resilient? In a museum dedicated to ancient Greek art, white is not simply a chromatic phenomenon. According to Héloïse Charital, it’s a construction on which racist and nationalist ideas have been based. Investigating this construction and the role of the museum, she asks: When is white, white enough? Through an animated diorama, Héloïse gives a fresh perspective on the various appropriations of Greek sculptures through time. By depicting objects in relation to their history within the museum, she questions the tactics of museum storytelling.

An augmented tour and a book exploring the parallel cultural battles and contradictions between the collection of historic artworks of the Rijksmuseum and emoji. Museum collections and emoji appear to exist in different worlds. One is fast, fun and digital, while the other is slow and serious, focused on history. Both, however, are visual collections with significant power to shape our culture. They can either perpetuate current biases or reshape our ideologies. By bringing these seemingly disparate collections into conversation, Lara Chapman presents a new perspective on the icons and symbols of our time. The project invites you to see the world ‘through the emoji looking glass’ and discover that nothing is quite what it seems.

The story of Belgrade’s post-war informal architecture, told by the houses themselves. After NATO bombed the city in 1999, reactionary urban structures grew out of its ashes. Now, the informal architecture of Belgrade is reliving its past as citizens want to overthrow the current dictatorial regime. Mara Siegel lets the buildings do the talking in an uncommon urban analysis. In a short film, the houses of Belgrade recall their experiences of 20 years ago. How their inhabitants hid inside them, how they fled from terror, and returned home after the war. Now, in 2019, they see what unfolds on the streets and share their concerns.

Live workshops designed to start a dialogue about conspiracy theories, helping people to place them in a context. In a period of increasing polarisation towards facts in media and institutions, it is easy to get stuck in discussions about what is true or not true. Yet, by understanding what conspiracy theories are and how they work, it is easier to know what to make of them. The workshops encourage people to ask questions and recognise a landscape where different belief systems exist. This is a more constructive way of approaching the idea of ‘truth’, Tiiu Meiner believes.

A new take on representing quantum gravity, breaking away from the traditional diagrams that leave most of us clueless. The uninspiring illustrations in physics books have not changed much in thirty years, even though the science behind it has greatly advanced. Frustrated with the absence of critical design in physics, Camila Kennedy searched for new ways to explain a complex theory to a broad public. Quantum gravity is impossible to see with your eyes, its particles trillions of times smaller than photons. Instead of trying to grasp that in misleading diagrams, Camila started storytelling – in comprehensible words. With a booming narration in a room filled with fog, listeners enter a different world, where fuzziness is the best descriptor.

An installation that ridicules the massive harvesting of user data, by having a fish create fake statistics. If you were on the internet today, your online presence has probably been tracked and analysed. Behavioural statistics govern our web environment. Even the tiniest cursor movement gets measured, recorded, and valued. ‘One-tailed’ is designed as a protest against this practice. This little goldfish perverts tracking mechanisms and methods. Its movements are captured by a camera and converted into cursor actions on the screen. Close enough to human actions, its swimming manoeuvres generate false statistics, disrupting the system in a gentle act of anarchy.

A project investigating the relationship between Instagram and theatre. For Fenna Wenselaar, Instagram is like a stage, with users as the writer, editor, director, set designer and actor of their own story. But what if our Insta-actions were to spill out into our offline existence? Selfies are split-second moments that gain a prolonged existence online. Imagine trying to hold the same pose or expression in the real world, all day long. Or what if we walked around with hashtags attached to us? In a series of videos, Fenna places our Instagram behaviour in the real world, revealing it for the staged act that it is.

This project deconstructs one photograph of the Gaza protests of 14 May 2018, the day the US embassy relocated to the disputed city of Jerusalem. The Palestine-Israel conflict is covered with sensational headlines and dramatic camera footage, especially through digital media. We witness performances staged by civilians, soldiers and media. In her film installation ‘A Stone’s Throw Away’, Ines Glowania reveals how the conflict is packaged as an information product. Countering the weaponised image of a conflict, the film reveals the performative signifiers behind news footage, and relates the heavily edited and constructed representation of news to everyday life. Ines’s human-scale installation draws spectators into Gaza, evoking the thoughts of each individual who has to see and reflect for themselves.

A research project that challenges the public perception of satellite technology and use. Satellites are seen as valuable sources of information for scientific purposes, but they have always been political and military tools as well. The boundary between the two is blurry, and the whole apparatus involved too. By zooming in on the refugee crisis in the Mediterranean Sea, Julian Peschel exposes the surveillance part. Two video projections showcase that side of the EU’s Earth observation programme Copernicus, juxtaposing the satellite’s perspective with the human interpretation and follow-up. Crucial data that is only shared with the controversial Border and Coast Guard Agency Frontex can lead to a rescue operation or end in a fatal cover-up.

A video self-portrait exploring contemporary female identity, balancing between freedom and oppression. Throughout history, ‘female identity’ was defined by male sculptors, painters, film directors and magazine editors. Nowadays, in the era of social media and selfies, women have the power to portray themselves. But do they really take the liberty to do so? By using the most-liked Instagram selfies as make-up for a 3D scan of her own face, Julie Patard illustrates her digital pursuit of perfection. If she wants to be a woman, she has to surrender to the restrictive codes of social media imagery that women collectively follow. Is it even possible to be feminine and free?

Exploring the conflicting ways that North Korean technological knowhow is portrayed in South Korean news media. North Korean technology comes across as highly advanced in some online news bulletins, while others paint a picture of it as hopelessly outdated, imagining a technological gap that would be impossible to bridge in a potential unification with South Korea. Both portrayals seem to stem from a desire to define this neighbouring country about which so little is known. By highlighting these two vastly different ‘truths’, June Park questions the way we perceive the information we encounter online or in the news and invites other people to do the same.

A place to lie down and do nothing, encouraging us to spend time and tune into our own thoughts. The information age is characterised by overload and immediacy. Ever-accelerating technologies dictate the pace of life. We have grown accustomed to racing from one thing to the next and seem to have forgotten how to sit down, do nothing and reflect. Headphones available in the space play a resonant soundscape generated from the surrounding noise that is morphed through a series of delays. An accompanying video uses slow textual iterations to further provide a backdrop for people to linger in their own, mental space.

A documentary uncovering the reality of recycling in China’s waste processing capital Wen’an. Following the country’s ban on imported waste, it has transitioned from boomtown to a city in collapse. For decades, China was the world’s largest importer of waste. The town of Wen’an processed millions of tonnes of waste plastics, but the ban changed everything. Minyang Liu visited Wen’an to see how locals are dealing with the ban and to understand what waste recycling really entails. She discovered that the story of recycling is incredibly complex, and not necessarily eco-friendly. There are many opposing interests, on multiple levels: human, environmental, political and financial.

The ‘Atlas of Internet Geography’ sheds light on the internet’s complex infrastructure by examining its geopolitical organisation. Internet is a physical network of cables, but it is not subject to clear legislation. Governments, businesses and individuals communicate through the internet. Even so, it is built by companies with unclear access to our personal information. Lucas Dubois questions our misguided understanding of the cloud, which allows the internet to redefine territories, borders and ownership. The installation consists of 50 models and maps of key internet nodes: United States, Brazil, Singapore, Egypt and GAFAM (Google, Amazon, Facebook, Apple and Microsoft). The project emphasises the importance of key players, whose connections represent a form of colonisation of internet infrastructure.

Revealing the hidden infrastructure that enables companies to track us with cookie technology. We often automatically consent to the use of cookies when confronted with a pop-up to get it out of the way quickly. But few of us understand what we are actually agreeing to. This project aims to change that, opening our eyes to how the data of thousands of millions of people ends up in the hands of anonymous others. Cookies give access to our browser behavior. This project visualises how the networks of companies that gather such data go far beyond the original website where we’ve given our consent.

Ground insect powder is shaped to resemble the original insect, visualising what this food is made of and forcing people to remain critical. Edible insects such as crickets are ground up for use in Western products to make them more appealing to eat. In this unrecognisable form, people are more likely to swallow the hype of insects as the ‘food of the future’ when perhaps they shouldn’t, believes Papon Sirimai. Insects are seen as a more sustainable alternative to livestock. Yet, is that really the case? By making insect-based food less abstract, Papon aims to initiate an important conversation about our food system and the way forward.

How commercial branding is used to stake a territorial claim on Dokdo Island, which is at the heart of a long-running dispute between South Korea and JapanFrom cookies, to cosmetics, to instant noodles, the iconic rocky peak of Dokdo Island is a common sight on South Korean packaging. It’s a form of marketing to feed patriotic feeling about the island that Japan considers theirs. SungEun Kim investigates a range of Dokdo-branded products and discovered that few, if any, of the ingredients used actually come from the island, or even from South Korea. The island has become an empty nationalistic symbol that is part of a complex geopolitical reality.

A study into the possibilities of visualising multiple datasets in digital geographic maps, using the latest technical advances. Geographic maps for digital screens are still made with an analogue mindset, usually based on a fixed scale. Now that linking multiple datasets is becoming more important, it might be better to stop using this fixed and therefore limiting scale. A map displaying airborne particles in the Netherlands between 2013 and 2016 serves as an example for a new way of map-making. Pixels in the map are given different colours for every year. While zooming in or out, the blend of colours reveals the change in air pollution over time.

A video installation that questions the meaning and life span of national symbols, like the oak tree for Germany. The oak is an archetype of strength, survival and loyalty, and its leaves have been used as symbols since ancient times. Many Germans consider it their national tree, the expression of German unity. But it was also used as an emblem during the Nazi regime. Is it still the right symbol to represent contemporary Germany? ’Roots’ shows glimpses of the huge digital archive on the oak tree that Wibke Bramesfeld compiled. It also presents the conversation she had with an oak, challenging the need for national symbolism in a society that is made up of so many different identities.

An installation illustrating the conflicting pressures women in South Korea face when it comes to marriage. The pressure is on from all sides. Jae Jang’s parents believe that her personal happiness hinges on marriage, while South Korean society sees marriage as a way to preserve traditional values while also boosting the birth rate. Adding to the stress are modern feminists with their message that modern women must rebel against this restrictive bond and enjoy the single life. With three walls showing three different video screens, Jae Jang illustrates how it feels to be a single South Korean woman trying to decide where she stands regarding marriage, while being surrounded by opposing perspectives.

Questioning the purpose of fencing in the contemporary world. Violence finds expression not only through human interaction but also in objects such as fences. The fence is the physical manifestation of our insecurities and creates ideological and spatial demarcations. It is a product of the struggle for control between humans, a technical solution for social conflicts, a symbolic expression of our desire to separate ourselves from the ‘other’. Billy Ernst examines three variations of an archetypal fence, isolating it from the intended context. By changing the material logic of metal in the three fences, they become soft objects that invite the user to physically interact with them, subverting its meaning of control and separation.

The archetype of a fluorescent orange watchtower raises awareness for the massive eradication of wild boar to protect the pig industry from a virus. In a quarantined territory of 36,000 hectares in France more than 1,000 wild boars have been eliminated at the beginning of 2019, out of fear for of spreading the African swine fever virus. In response, Chloé Guillemart raises the question why our (over)consumption of pork goes before the preservation of wild fauna. With souvenir objects, a boar call device and interviews with locals, the tower serves as a plea for the recognition of this area as the biggest Wild Animal Memorial Park.

A reworked Natural History Museum display, not for stuffed animals but for humans, questioning our anthropocentric, dominant take on nature. Considering the increasingly precarious state of nature as a consequence of human domination, Eva Jack explores a new perspective: one that does not place mankind as superior, but instead acknowledges interspecies entanglement and dependency. She treats museum visitors to the animal’s point of view – inside the diorama. They are faced with a video that dissects and reworks the conventions of a museum setup. Reinterpreting familiar narratives, which are often biased and based on politics, is the first step towards a more equal and meaningful relationship with ‘other’ animals.

A self-broadcasting bed that live streams straight to Instagram, questioning the merging of our physical and digital identity. In the age of minimal housing, physical space is being replaced with virtual space. We work, shop and socialise online without having to leave our bed. As a reflection of contemporary society, Felicity Morris presents this intimate domestic object as a site for public broadcasting. Surrounded by selfie sticks and blogger ring lights, her bed becomes the stage for a series of live streams, inviting the viewer into this private domain. The mattress acts as a green screen that can situate her anywhere whilst in bed, and the static blanket lets her show or hide as much as desired.

The semi-legal trade across the border of Spanish enclave Ceuta in Morocco inspired Ismaël Rifai to develop a series of objects ‘designed’ by the border. Every day thousands of Moroccans travel to Ceuta for tax-free items, which they can freely import to Morocco because of a lack of commercial customs in the Tarajal borders. Crossing the border requires special techniques for packing and carrying the goods. Drawing upon the concept of ‘the border as a producer of design’ this project is based around the different actors involved in this informal ‘factory’. The designs of a table, a chair, a lamp and a blanket embody the changing appearance of an object confronted with the border

Kodai Shimizu predicts a future in which a new guild of ‘craft-techmen’, combining the skills of the engineer, designer, and craftsman, will create new home appliances that can be easily fixed when broken. With integrated craft techniques home appliances can be repaired when broken and handed down to the next generation. These new artifacts will make people realise that wealth is much more a matter of intangible values. Conductive threads sewed into several home appliances facilitate disassembly for reparation, while also adding new functionalities. By rotating one part of the device, the threads adjust to different levels of contact, causing voltage variation. This simple system can be adapted to different functions by reprogramming the accompanying microcomputer.

A carefully designed process of clay recycling brings forth a set of movements that can help participants in the performance to overcome the fear of death. In a time of spiritual loss, all our actions are rationalised and result oriented. But what if the only purpose of an object’s production would be to produce an emotion, rather than material profit? The project uses the vocabulary of a production system in a performative installation in which a participant and an operator produce and recycle a clay object. The production follows four steps surrounding death: deposition, transit, separation and remembrance. Dry repetition of the movements brings the focus to body and mind, allowing emotions to flow.

titel: Machina Communicatio Synthetica – A Living Smartphone
inhoud: A reinvention of smartphone technology, using synthetic DNA to create an environmentally friendly organism that we can interact with in a more natural way. Recent developments in synthetic biology open up the possibility of biological machines, leading to a new relationship with our devices. Intrigued by that thought, and aiming for a less polluting phone industry, Lukas Jurk proposes to design DNA to redesign the smartphone. Instead of the sealed inanimate boxes that we hold to our ears now, his ‘living smartphone’ interacts with us organically. Residing on our skin, this ‘fellow being’ responds to body movement. There’s no need for electricity as it feeds on blood glucose: from product and user to extra organ and host.

A pop-up strip club that gives strippers full political, financial and bodily autonomy. Imbalanced power structures, transphobia, sexism and racial dis¬crimination are still common in the strip-club industry. It is time for an upgrade that meets the needs of contemporary society: ‘Striptopia’ offers strippers the tools to create their own working conditions. The Striptopia app communicates with wearable technology to ensure extra boundaries for consent. The app also allows customers to send tips straight to the strippers’ bank accounts. Strippers keep 90 per cent of their income – 10 per cent goes to sex worker foundations. With a complete set of portable equipment, stripper collectives can set up their own club anywhere they like.

A transdisciplinary platform facilitating the exchange of knowledge about soil and the sharing of it as a resource. Global soil loss is not only an ecological problem but also a cultural, social and political issue. The project explores transplantation as a way to revive and alter soils, without artificial influence, while challenging societal frameworks such as the ownership of resources. By fusing art and science, and using techniques such as an imaging method and transplant tests. Soils of different origins and agricultural treatments are inoculated in a test plot designed as a biogeographical map. Mirrored and monitored through soil chroma images, the results form an analogue and virtual archive of knowledge, displaying multiple potentials.

A piece of the Separation Wall in East Jerusalem that travels the world to increase recognition, resonating the sound from both sides. Studying life around the wall, Nivi Lehavi discovered that it is possible to hear each other when standing on either side, through the gaps between the construction units. This encouraged her to observe this barrier as a space of its own, where opposite voices merge. She collected the ‘sound of the wall’ by planting a recording device in one of its gaps. This mobile replica of a concrete unit distributes that sound in contexts outside of Jerusalem. It prompts recognition of the wall’s existence and imparts a different perception of the complex situation that borders represent.

A modular system to create templates for sawing and drilling to guide people with different skill levels in woodworking workshops. Automation, digitisation and efficiency alienate people from manufacturing processes, product value and the joy of work. Re-humanising production systems by designing open and inclusive processes of making is of utmost importance. In weekly workshops in a home for the elderly participants engaged in making a construction system using the guiding templates. The group activity revealed the participants’ strong desire to be useful in society. The approach can be adapted to different professions outside woodwork, challenging capitalistic ideas and preventing the loss of sensory working activities and the exclusion of people.

A clothing collection made of Hansan-Mosi fabric and Hanji paper that reappropriates Korean heritage. Fast fashion provides immediate satisfaction at a low cost, but leads to massive ethical and environmental issues and puts an end to traditional textile crafts. Sun Lee presents a more balanced and circular collection inspired by Korean heritage, introducing traditional production methods and materials in a contemporary context. These handmade garments are entirely composed of biodegradable Hansan-Mosi fabric and Hanji paper – buttons included – representing the philosophy of ephemerality. Old techniques are combined with new techniques, and modular pieces can be worn in several ways. The result is a multiple layered collection that passes on tradition to a new generation.

A mask with an integrated breath test that measures, analyses and visualises our physical and mental health with every breath. Each human body hosts trillions of microorganisms. Their composition and diversity influence our health, balance our immune system, protect us against disease, and influence our behaviour and mood. Understanding how these organisms interact with their human host could explain different aspects of many complex diseases and help to achieve better physical and mental well-being. Valerie Daude developed a mask that creates a dialogue between host and microbes. The integrated breath test measures the diversity of our gut microbes. The result is displayed on the mask through a colour code called the Microbiome Diversity Index.

Electrical Parasites’ are objects designed to collect and convert waste energy in the home into usable electricity. While public awareness of the global energy crisis has increased substantially, individuals still have difficulty finding ways to contribute to the solution. Meanwhile, in a typical urban household a lot of energy is lost. Most household appliances generate waste heat as a by-product of their functions. Using generic parts and universal DIY production methods, Yiqian Bao created small ‘parasites’ that convert this heat into free power that can be used to charge various devices. At the same time, the project might inspire manufacturers to improve the energy efficiency of their products by including simple mechanisms in their design process.

A series of machine-made sculptures of pure sulphur, shaped and solidified by flowing water. The sculptures show the passing of time, through the acceleration of a naturally slow process. Historically sulphur is closely linked to concepts of hell and alchemy, because of its flammable and odorous features. Paradoxically, sulphur is an essential for all life. The project looks into the the cultural, environmental and historical aspects of the element that is important for the world's economy. The sculptures show sulphur in its, rarely seen, pure form. A two metre ‘triptych’ made by using traditional inlay and engraving techniques, exhibits the myths as well as the industrial and geological cycles of this rather underestimated material.

A film exploring the environmental, economic and geopolitical consequences of a society relying on rare metals and looking to a possible new source: Polymetallic Nodules in the deep sea. Metals are now essential for nearly all our electronic, military, and ‘green’ technologies. Given the continuous depletion of land deposits of minerals, mining companies are turning to the oceans. However, these fragile habitats are located in areas beyond national jurisdiction, meaning they belong to everyone – or to no one. The project investigates the challenges and complexities that lie ahead and allows us a closer look into the natural elements that shape a significant share of our material world.

The Six-Winged Chicken and Other Mythical Animals from the Food Industry uses the format of a children’s book to describe a mythical world of animals that can be found today. This project is rooted in the stories and the challenges created by globalised food production. It attempts to explore the myths and share the mysteries that create personal belief and collective doubt. With reference to the Middle Ages when people told stories about mythical animals like unicorns, this almanac of mythical animals of the food industry presents a world in which the six-winged chicken and the spineless pig are as real as the superior dairy cow and the cut-price chicken.

A machine that treats the physical traces of tidal waves on the beach as sound waves. ’Streaming Sandwaves’ presents a language that was unheard until now. Axel Coumans has captured the dialogue between the North Sea and its shore – not by recording the sound of the waves, but by recording their traces in the sand. Axel has teamed up with the Embassy of the North Sea to give a voice to the ever-interacting water and sand. His self-built device laser scans the intricate patterns that the outgoing tide leaves on the shore and then carves the same groove into a master album on site – in a simple bucket on the beach.

Here’s an installation that actually values smoking, encouraging the use of medical herbs to benefit from their properties. Smoking is a harmful habit, a ritual practised and despised at the same time. However, according to traditional medicine, shamanism and certain household beliefs, the fumes of some plants are thought to bring precious benefits that are said to be intensified in this state. A set of glass objects facilitate the inhalation of smoke from medical plants, combining recreational rituals with healing and well-being. Thus, the project reflects on our medical habits and questions blind trust in prescription drugs, while proposing to turn a harmful daily habit into a positive one.

Creative interventions to raise the status and public profile of those who maintain urban plants and parks. It’s as if the people who tend the city’s gardens are invisible, Cécile Espinasse noticed. Yet, they make an important contribution to the community. With their gardening know-how, they can add even more value if locals engage with them. Dutch company Ergon employs those with physical and mental disabilities in public maintenance. Cecile spent time with the Eindhoven company as an artist-in-residence. Her redesigned uniforms, school workshops and exhibition all invite more interaction with the ‘green experts’ in our midst, giving them a greater sense of pride.

The Africa Biogas Partnership Programme (ABPP) aims to construct 100,000 biogas plants in five African countries, providing half a million people with a sustainable energy source. Jeffe Van Holle designed interactive promotion tools to accelerate this goal. The promotion campaign aims to interest small farmers who sell their produce at local markets in biogas as a sustainable and clean alternative for wood and charcoal as energy source for domestic use. Collective market clean-ups focus on the abundance of unsold organic waste that can be used to produce biogas. Two ‘pressure chairs’ demonstrate the easy use of the gas. Sitting on the gas-filled cushion brings the gas under the pressure needed to activate the energy source.

The responsive website eatinthisorder.com enables the user to evaluate and reflect on his individual relationship to food and healthy eating. Cooking shows, cookbooks, diets, and social media drive food behaviours into choices that can become entangled in obsessive rules of engagement. Eating rules, when applied too rigidly, can lead to obsessive healthy eating and living, a disorder called Orthorexia Nervosa. According to psychotherapist John Robbemond one reason for this lies in the difficulty to reflect one’s own rules when it comes to food. A simple visual test reveals the realities of our eating behaviours which invite self-reflection and examination. The results help us reconsider our relationship to food, which can prevent eating disorders from developing.

Botanical bodies’ investigates the possibility to use plants for the creation of human compatible organs. Vegetal and human tissues share microscopic similarities making blending the two conceivable. Scientific developments show the potential of vegetal matter to replace human organs. This project pushes these current developments to a speculative level, considering the implications it would have if we could replace our original organs with plant-based ones, becoming more and more hybrid with every transplant. The project visualises how the physical body could progressively merge with the vegetal world, for instance by replacing human bones by poplar wood. The overarching question being: What happens if we consider our body not as an independent set of organs, but as an organism constantly evolving toward a symbiosis with plants?

A series of performative acts as a metaphor to reveal our close connection to the earth, and therefore to climate change. It seems as if we have spent the last century trying to distance ourselves from our bond with nature, believes Paula Schulenburg. Only when we recognise that we are part of the network of life, can we hope to tackle the cause of the current environmental crisis – our own behaviour. Small scenes and poetic acts speak of our human experience as mentally rising beyond our surroundings, while at the same time we are unable to transcend the physicality of our earth-bound existence.

These water collectors are the result of an ongoing research project on how to harvest water in the urban environment. As the threat to Earth’s natural resources rises exponentially, our ‘available-on-demand’ mentality needs to change, says Shaakira Jassat. Her project seeks to reconsider the value of water, instead of taking it for granted. At a domestic scale, there is a tea machine that condenses water vapour from the air. It functions on its own timeframe; you just have to wait until there is enough for a cup of tea. On a larger scale, a modular architectural panel collects the rain that naturally runs down the façade, storing the water for later use.

A series of objects designed for midnight periods of wakefulness. Ever tried going to bed early and waking up in the middle of the night before settling down for a second round of sleep until morning? This was the norm in pre-industrial times. Inspired by this two-shift sleeping pattern, Sixtine Blandin discovered a new world of conscious downtime, opening space for thought and creativity. Aiming to alter current sleeping habits, ‘Dorveille’ includes a journal for jotting down nightly musings, a warm, duvet-style wrap, a glass of water and a clock that makes time appear to go more slowly. Together they make the most of those precious nocturnal hours.

Japanese Knotweed is one of the most invasive and hard to eradicate plants in Europe. This mobile unit is meant to restrain the plant by turning it into a food resource. Japanese Knotweed is notorious for its quick spreading, destructive properties and for being almost impossible to get rid of. But instead of destroying it, why not invest and exploit its qualities? The plant is edible and considered a delicacy in its country of origin, Japan. The edible spring shoots can be used to make a nice syrup with a taste comparable to rhubarb. Cutting the shoots will prevent the plant from growing taller. For this, a mobile syrup lab is made, that will also serve as a communication tool.

A rescue operation for the almost destroyed coral reefs of Curacao, offering beach-goers the chance to make a sustainable, low-cost and fun contribution. In 2010 Curacao was hit by hurricane Tomas, destroying 50 per cent of the island’s coral reefs. As almost everything that it could thrive on was washed away, the coral is in desperate need of help. ‘Kas’i koral’, invites tourists and locals to cast a plaster donut on the beach as a fertile growing ground for baby corals. This simple do-it-yourself kit is available at the marine biology centre on the beach. Prepare the plaster with seawater, pour your donut and sink it in the sea ten minutes later. It will attract the fish to instigate the growth of algae that coral polyps feed on.

A collection of splints for fingers and wrists made of delicate copper wire that look more like jewellery than medical accessories. Wearables and identity are very much related. When it comes to splints, the wearer's choice is quite limited. Often massive and unaesthetic, a splint is synonymous with having a condition. ‘Minimal’ was conceived to not draw attention to one’s medical circumstances. These splints are made of simple copper lines, using as little material as possible. The use of recycled copper is sustainable, inexpensive and a nod to the fact that copper is essential to the good health of connective tissue. To conceal the silver lines of the soldering each splint incorporates silver pieces, that add to its beauty.

What happens to our waste when it leaves our homes? This question led to a study into the possibilities of using bottom ash as a resource. Bottom ash is the non-combustible residue after household waste is burned in waste-to-energy-plants. In the Netherlands one person’s household waste produces an average of 57,5 kg of bottom ash per year. Can this leftover be reused in useful quality products? This extensive investigation into the value of bottom ash documented both current applications of the material and possible new uses. These include a terrazzo-like stone material and wood stain. Such applications show that value can be regained from such a grey and lifeless matter as bottom ash.

Coloured glassware that can be stacked in endless combinations to create new hues. Normally we keep plates and bowls hidden behind cupboard doors. Why not allow them to transcend the functional as aesthetic eyecatchers worth putting on show in the interior? This collection is made to be seen, inviting attention and interaction. The transparent quality of this glassware allows you to engage with the objects in a playful way, adding an extra dimension. Placing different coloured plates and bowls on top of each other creates new and surprising outcomes that you can experiment with yourself.

Reality Is the Best Story’ is a small design exhibition with a personal view on conceptual product design, in which three design objects can be viewed from different angles. Four years of education at the Design Academy Eindhoven has transformed Ken Tsunoda in countless ways. However, his first impression that conceptual product design could sometimes be far-fetched didn’t change. He decided to make the most of that, using the skills he gained through his DAE education. Three design objects are presented and described in multiple, completely different contexts and stories. They show how contexts are the primary goals to be communicated, with the physical design objects serving merely as props of the stories. At the same time, it can be looked at as an attempt to push forward the boundaries of conceptual product design.

A playful interactive installation in the middle of the city inviting people passing by to step out of their routine and open up to new experiences. When we travel, we like to explore and try new things. At home, on the other hand, we always end up going to the same places. ‘Noevo’ recreates this traveller’s mindset at home to help people rediscover the city with a new eye. Intrigued by the installation, the passer-by stops to play, steering a ball through a labyrinth. By reaching the centre of the maze, he receives the ball with a message inside, suggesting a surprising activity to do today in the city.

The Māyā* pieces take a different view on lamps. By changing their position these frames allow you to play with light and shadow. Inspired by the geometric use of light by architects like Tadao Ando and Luís Barragan, these pieces present light in a graphic form and at the same time reinterpret the exciting feeling of opening a window to a new and brighter world. Frames of steel with built-in led lighting are fixed to the wall on one side, so that their position can be changed as if you would open a window. The light switches on by opening the frame and the shape of the light cast on the wall changes as the frame is moved.

This is a comfortable armchair that easily unfolds into a one-person bed designed for open spaces. A lot of armchair beds or sofa beds are placed in an open space or a space which is not a bedroom. When unfolded these beds offer no protection or privacy. When used as a bed, the shell of this chair creates a little nook, offering the user some privacy. The chair unfolds very easily in just two steps and could be used in a living room, a hotel room or public areas such as airport lounges, where people want to take a nap. A drawer in the back can store a blanket.

Three kitchenware collections based on three still lifes. What makes a collection? Mathilde Philipponat believes that the objects in a collection interact like characters in a story. Her three collections were inspired by still lifes by Jean Siméon Chardin, Jan Groover and Maurice de Vlaminck. Taking the narrative outline used to construct stories, with a starting point, a disruption and a resolution, Mathilde remodelled each still life in Rhino to create shapes that she then translated into materials to reflect the essence of the original image. Glass, ceramic and metal convey the light reflections in Chardin, colourless wood and metal capture the mystery in Groover, and ceramics express the fragile state in De Vlaminck.

A family of bathroom fittings. The surface of copper, brass and bronze changes over time as a result of oxidation and use. In creating a family of bathroom fittings, Pauline Neiser wanted to exploit this effect as a way of letting users personalise products, thereby letting them become more beautiful and vivid with the passage of time. Her goal challenges the norm in industry, where products that are no longer ‘new’ and ‘shiny’ are dumped and replaced. Water flows out through the angled slit in the shelf, and the same angle and curves appear in the taps and shower head, uniting the collection, emphasising the flow of water, and inviting users to touch them.

A new type of 3D printing that uses bacteria to bind silica powder into glass products. Nature can be a great inspiration for sustainable innovations. Traditional glass production requires a lot of heat. Binding silica with the help of bacteria would allow cold production of glass, minimising CO2 emissions, while making the process less labour intensive and more cost efficient. This is still a speculative project, inspired by the use of bacteria to form bio-concrete from sand. More research is needed to find the right type of bacteria to solidify silica into glass. When found, the process would create unique products, because even if the 3D printing software can be fully controlled, the bacteria can’t.

To extend the boundaries of inflatable products, Satomi Minoshima designed a series of leather-covered inflatable furniture. The advantage of inflatable products is that they are light and portable. However, they generally have a short lifespan and the vinyl material usually looks cheap, even if it is made well. Inflatable furniture is therefore seen as a quick fix for temporary situations. The couch, chair and ottoman are all covered with real leather. Leather is a natural material, rich with texture and has a long lifespan. The more it is used and aged, the more the value increases. This makes the value of the inflatable furniture increase with time.

Skin-coloured bags serve as a metaphor for the role skin colour plays in how others judge us, without even knowing us. Although we are heading towards a globalised, post-racial era, where one’s skin colour is less of a critical factor, discrimination based on skin colour is still present in most societies. Skin Tote conveys the idea that the skin is just a container carrying one’s personality inside. The message is communicated via a series of photos of people and bags matching their skin colour, aimed at spreading the aesthetic quality and diversity of skin colours. The contents of the physical bags reflect the weight of our skin, which is 6.3 per cent of our body weight.

These sunshades originated from the question whether one material could be used both in a flexible and a more rigid state. A material with flexible, rigid or more dense properties as needed, would allow products to be made from just one material, instead of having to be made from two. Sunshades can be very muggy and usually block all the sunlight. Sometimes however, partial shadow is more desirable. These sunshades of woven polypropylene ropes are partially heated to increase density locally. Thus, the sunshades provide different shade patterns, comparable to a tree’s foliage that gives shelter from the sun while still letting the light come through.

A collection of five sensory objects that are intended to provide comfort in times of mental distress. Research shows that workplace stress has reached near-epidemic levels. The ever-increasing demands of the modern workplace intensify the pressure on employees. This project aims to show that our emotional health is equally as important as our physical state. Varvara Lazareva designed five objects for relaxation: a curved wooden massager to help reduce tension in the neck and shoulder and prevent migraines; a silicone egg that vibrates with the rhythm of a calm heart; an exercise footrest to reduce stress in the leg and stimulate blood flow; a breathing mask to counter hyperventilation; a hand toy that brings relaxation and concentration through repetitive movements.

Flexible pads for knees, elbows and wrists, providing protection in medium-impact sports such as skateboarding, basketball, roller-skating, skiing, snowboarding and suchlike. Essential for many sports, protective pads often limit movement. That’s because adequate protection and flexibility are difficult to reconcile. Virgile Tanguy has come up with a solution with Atome, a printed plastic that can be shaped to cover different parts of the body. Although the prototype is made of PLA, Atome is ideally made of 3D-printed nylon or carbon fibre. The structure is inspired by chain mail and consists of interconnected triangular modules that not only provide very strong protection but also allow for flexible body movement.

Sevenclicks is a brainstorm tool that allows you to discover new connections between your subjects of interest, creating a pathway that brings you from A to X in seven clicks. In psychology creativity is mostly defined as combining distant concepts together. Research has shown that broader thoughts are linked to successful ideas. Therefore, Sevenclicks is a tool to stimulate broad thinking by taking the user from his initial topic to unexpected, yet related subjects. The website Sevenclicks.org is a creative research tool that takes the user on a path through the vast and connected knowledge base of Wikipedia. The result is a seven-page glossary, containing the seven chosen topics, which can then be saved or shared with others.

A range of tools that provide improved working conditions and a distinguished identity for the growing numbers of freelancers in semi-public spaces. Freelancing has gained popularity, even though it misses the benefits of employed work. Lacking an office, many freelancers open their laptops at coffee bars, trying to get the job done in the public environment. ‘New Office’ offers help with claiming their space and boosting their importance. A visual identity, with a playful reference to the traditional office, makes freelancers stand out from the crowd. A fake shirt for video calls, a reversible vest with a ‘free’ and a ‘busy’ side, or a barrier to mark the working area highlights their position in a fun way.

A magazine that raises awareness about the current situation in the EU and stresses the importance of a united Europe. There is a mood of crisis across Europe. The EU feels like an unapproachable “club of old intellectuals” – not exactly easy to identify with. And let’s be honest, what do we really know about our political and economic union? Anna Zimmerman does not want her generation to yield to the pessimists out of ignorance; ‘EUPHORIC Magazine’ presents an informative, optimistic approach. The first edition focuses on European Identity, trying to make this vague feeling more tangible. The divergent perspectives of fourteen young people from all over of Europe are meant to inspire others to actively shape their future as EU citizens.

A new way of looking at the city; instead of mapping the built environment, Bloeme Groenewold registers people’s feelings towards their surroundings. How do the people in Eindhoven experience their city? Which emotions are attached to squares, bridges or buildings? Analysing these emotions could provide valuable information for urban planning and lead to more mutual understanding. ’Sense of Place’ has defined a shape and colour for ten different feelings: from a red triangle for fear to a green wave for ease or a purple arch for pride. Placed on the map of Eindhoven, they show interesting patterns of feelings in various parts of town.

A living room as a curated staged decor, built to be a photographic image. The modern interior exists as an image to be liked and shared on social media. In ‘HomeSet’, Boris Brucher illustrates the gap between representation and reality by highlighting the divorce between image and shape, intention and comfort, picture and experience. Platforms like Instagram and Airbnb have widened that gap. Boris constructed an ensemble out of scaffolding and upholstered fabric, and draped it with images of popular furniture (Jeanneret chairs and a Perriand stool) published in influential interior magazines and loved by social media superstars. The deliberate mismatch between the photographed object and the actual shape emphasises the superficiality of our image-saturated world.

A hacked version of Vogue, based on the portrayal of beauty in the past 50 years of the magazine. Advertising in this famous fashion magazine is saturated with a certain beauty standard, captured in idyllic images. But what does such visual perfection convey to ordinary readers? Trends come and go, but, as five decades of Vogue advertising reveal, one quality never goes out of fashion: confidence. Mimicking this trait, Crys Leung photoshopped her own face into the original images to reveal and understand the tools that magazines use to manipulate the reader. It’s about making them buy into a parallel world, where there is no insecurity or sadness.

A furniture collection that reflects the effects of high tide in Venice, creating a new aesthetic with references to the classic republican style. As the sea level is rising, floods in Venice are getting worse. Water enters houses and restaurants, but there is still no solid policy to save the city. Instead of ignoring the problem like many Venetians do, Federico Rosa revives awareness with a stylish yet worrisome design. These pieces of furniture may look like traditional classics, but they are actually trendsetters. The remnants of the high tide – molluscs, barnacles and seaweed – are cast into bronze ornaments for their legs, warning the world of what the future will bring.

A reinterpretation of the myth of Narcissus, drawing a parallel with contemporary self-adoration in the virtual world. Ferran Avila shows that the old myths are still relevant. Replacing the water surface from the story with a pair of modern VR glasses, he compares Narcissus’s obsessive love for his own reflection to self-glorification in the digital realm. Inspired by the hip hop scene – a growing ground for ego-boosting – Ferran stages an album release in an aesthetic museum setting. This moving sculpture shows how we can endlessly augment ourselves, building delusionary alter egos that are hard to let go of.

A documentation of emotions generated by the world’s most popular sport. Thousands of fans gather weekly, annually, and every four years to witness ninety minutes of play, hoping that their team proves victorious. Analysing the impact of this theatre of emotions, Isabelle Mauduit shows that what matters is not the result but the emotional fluctuations throughout the game. By dissecting in book form this environment where emotions are highly stimulated and entirely simulated. Each minute spans three spreads that identify the name and time of an emotional event, capture it in a ‘photographic window’, and conclude with the football commentator’s account.

A video that explores the duality of attitudes towards the Catholic Church in Poland through interviews with family members and public displays of tension. The video features on Julia Romanowska’s family members, footage of demonstrations, and an artwork based on the School of Athens by Raphael, which speaks of duality within one discipline. The painting is overlaid with imagery that reflects the current state of the Polish Catholic Church, which still wields substantial power. To merge the polarised pro-church and anti-church narratives that not only dominate the public space but also fracture the internal fabric of individual families. The project draws on Julia’s experience of Catholic teaching and confrontation with the falsities of those who taught it.

A life vest made for success. It will arm you with undeniable confidence, as it instantly pushes you into a ‘power posture’. If you want to live up to expectations, you have to measure up to the polished picture of a self-assured professional. Linda Vilumsone ironically presents a quick fix for those who struggle with that oppressive framework. The rules for appearing confident are simple: back straight, shoulders out, head up. That is exactly what this vest does. Wear it to a presentation or meeting that makes you feel insecure. When in doubt, just pull the trigger: the vest will inflate and expand your confidence on the spot.

Three robotic creatures, inspired by the Mars rovers. But instead of exploring the possibility of life on a faraway planet, they evaluate life on Earth. Since 2003, NASA has had three rovers on Mars, called Spirit, Curiosity and Opportunity. Their goal: to find out if the human race could ever inhabit Mars. But did we already give up on Earth? If these rovers were engineered for Earth, could they teach us something about human behaviour? Meet Apathy, Denial and Misfortune. They collectively draw attention to the destructive attitude that we have towards our own planet. Their disrupted functionality highlights the human struggle to solve local issues, while looking for answers elsewhere.

These postcards show popular instagrammed landmarks – with a compilation of selfies that were made on the exact same spot. In the age of digital self-promotion, Instagram posts depict us as enviable individuals, having a unique experience in untouched nature or at a city gem. In fact, these landmarks have turned into crowded tourist attractions; there is a huge gap between the story that we tell online and the reality on site. Greetings from Kuang Si Falls, Antelope Canyon or the Eiffel Tower, and from all the other people that were there too. Adding a selection of the numerous visitors that digitally posted their picture to an ‘old-fashioned’ postcard places the story in a contemporary perspective.

E.topia is a stop-motion movie about an Instagram robot that ends up on a fictive electronics dump in Africa. Changes in fashion and planned obsolescence mean that over 40 tonnes of electronic waste are dumped every year. Marion Foulquier art directed and produced a film to raise awareness about our relation to modern technology in our digitalised world. Set in a fictive colossal e-waste dump and one of most poisonous places in the world, Marion’s seven-minute animation film features Violet, an Instagram robot. Found and repaired by a girl, Violet follows her new owner into a world she wasn't designed for. This meeting is the confrontation between two realities that were not supposed to meet.

Contemplative Streams’ is a video installation that invites viewers to tune into nature’s pace. The viewer can observe blue and golden hours across the globe through live recorded webcam footage. Blue and golden hours mark the beginning and ending of the day, both in nature and in our personal time. Displayed as a continuous stream, these light events become an open invitation for contemplation and peace of mind. Two screens display blue and golden hours respectively from subsequent places around the world. They offer a window on the bustle in these places. A third screen displaying a day and night map of the world and a timetable of sky shades gives a full picture of the day in blue and gold.

The sculptural objects designed by Michael Strebel are meant as portals, physical access points for digital experiences using augmented reality. Increasing electronic, digital and virtual functionalities in the environment of the future give us a chance to imagine a new function for physical objects and spaces. The project investigates how we can integrate digital practices in our daily lives beyond the computer screen. The intermediary objects in this project offer smartphone-users the entrance to a multitude of digital worlds. This shows how objects and spaces can become a kind of memory bank for diverse digital experiences. In short, the project investigates how augmented realty could create a whole new way of life.

An illustrated story and installation that raises awareness of the need to change our ways. We all know that pollution is an enormous global threat to the continued existence of life on Earth. We want to do something, but don’t know how. The scale of the problem is too big. Shrinking the situation into the pages of a book can help us connect with our reality. Nam, Woe and Leav inhabit a fictional world where they face issues relating to todays big problems. Their plight symbolises our global predicament. Through these characters, it’s easier to think about topics that feel too confronting to deal with.

A performance piece symbolising the sense of loss when big corporations leave the city that has grown to rely on them. In the South Korean city of Ulsan, the economic recession saw Hyundai Heavy Industries decide to go. The shipyard is Ulsan’s lifeblood and its inhabitants stand to lose everything. The move is part of a larger global pattern of what happens when these crucial companies leave. People try and push an enormous wheel up a sloped track. The visual evokes the incredible effort that locals have invested and the heavy sorrow weighing them down after the company that they have worked so hard for is now seeking its fortune elsewhere.

A video installation exploring the blurry line between reality and advertising in user-generated makeup content on YouTube. This project reflects on current social media influencer marketing in the beauty industry and how brands are promoting their products subconsciously to ad-resistant millennials. A collection of user generated makeup tutorials is simultaneously displayed on a screen, all showing women in the process of applying makeup while talking about their personal lives. Is this really a reality or is it another face of advertising displayed as a reality?

A film that highlights why the issue of sexual consent is still so problematic. When it comes to sex, consent remains much less clear-cut than it should be, believes Oriane Rondeau. For her, the ongoing objectification of women in modern pop culture creates the wrong expectations among men and women. Many young girls don’t even realise that saying no is an option. In a series of interviews, women reveal their experiences about consent. Oriane combines voice-over extracts with sexualised images of women portrayed in advertising and the media to reveal where things are going wrong.

Polycreative’ is a new term and approach, an understanding of collaborations as creative relationships between multiple individuals. This project focuses on representing and celebrating these relationships through cake. Increased visibility, communication and information access through social media are changing the way we work together. Viewing a collaboration as a creative relationship means consent, appreciation, curiosity and dialogue can be shared in a new light. It all starts with five cake stands by five designers for one cake baker. Five ritual designers, plus photographers, video artists, eaters and viewers complete the experience. The final outcomes become secondary; primary aspects are the communication, the many different media used, and the different emotions experienced.

Furniture that refers to and reflects contemporary culture. Figurative furniture disappeared over the centuries. By eliminating decoration, we focused on essential needs instead, seen as geometrical and abstract. Orson Van Beek breathes new life into the figurative with screens, wires and cables. The image depicted onto the screen forms a simple no-content grid. The display is an empty container. Once someone sits on the chair, they become the content. Constructed from ordinary cables, the lamps represent our digital dependency. Wires become the centrepiece, not things that are hidden. The chair supported by cables expresses the dynamics of a messy composition.

A translation of personal and gathered experiences of the physical symptoms and sensations brought on by depression and anxiety disorders, using textiles and clothing to create sensory simulations. To create a visual and tangible understanding of the hidden physical symptoms of mental illness. These sensations can be all-consuming to the individual experiencing them, yet they are rarely manifest, making them hard to comprehend as an outside observer. Paisley Fried designed pieces around areas where symptoms manifest: stomach, chest, arms, throat and head. They simulate incessant tingling and build-up of energy, excessive weight, dragging, separation of body and skin, waves of heat and tension, sensations of suffocation, smothering and discomfort within your skin.

An eight-minute video offers unexpected solutions for sea waste. The huge amounts of trash drifting in the oceans are often felt as too big a problem to tackle. ‘Sea You There’ is a fresh way to raise awareness for the problem, helping us to think differently about the issue. The story of two researchers looking into the myth of left and right shoes washing up on different shores, leads to redesigns of products most commonly found among ocean trash. What if we designed plastic bottles, lighters and plastic bags so that they will wash ashore, instead of endlessly drifting around in the ocean?

A clothing collection that protects wearers against electromagnetic radiation from wireless devices, introducing conductive materials from industrial gear into everyday outfits. Most of us live in a smog of electromagnetic radiation from wireless technology. We don't yet know what the long-term impact will be on our health. But for those who prefer to be on the safe side, ‘Feel at EASE’ offers an attractive solution without the need to disconnect or unplug. Integrating conductive metals like copper or silver into the fabric partly blocks electromagnetic waves. A multifunctional jacket, a sporty jumpsuit and a casual hoody are meant to counter potential damage from keeping a phone in your pocket, working with a laptop on your knees, or passing a transmission tower.

titel: Police Training – How to deal with young ex-prisoners?
inhoud: A series of educational animation videos, highlighting how the police can help tackle serious social issues like youth recidivism. Roxane de Jong renders a complicated subject – the successful reintegration of young ex-detainees – in a video tutorial for the Police Academy and YouTube. An accessible how-to video can be a strong tool to reduce the alarming 63 per cent of repeat youth offenders. Roxane interviewed policemen, criminal lawyers and psychologists to develop an approach that can lower the risk of regression. This tutorial analyses the problem, identifies the social partners involved, and offers hands-on advice. ‘Police Training’ is a tool that helps the police help people at risk.

This installation works in conjunction with the VR experience ‘La Peur Bleue’. It represents the process of turning the war memoir of Samuel Picot’s grandfather into a VR-experience, changing the way the story is told. “By turning his memoir book into VR, a medium that my grandfather has no ability to access on his own, I also created a bridge between two generations, a common interest,” says Samuel. “The representation of this process in itself being just as valuable as the result.” Through a film, a series of pictures, some relics from the past, and the book itself, this process is shown together with the elements that helped the project come together.

The story of good versus evil, taken from two very different contexts − fantasy films and the Bible − and brought together in a single video installation. Sylke van der Heiden grew up within the strict religious community of the Reformed Liberated Church. Films such as Harry Potter, Narnia and Lord of the Rings were considered sinful and dangerous, with their portrayal of evil forces rising up against the good. Yet the battle against evil also lies at the heart of Sylke’s religion. By mixing fragments of fantasy films and Bible passages, Sylke seeks a way to navigate her conflicting feelings towards the church in a visual way that others can also understand.

A collection of informative jigsaw puzzles, visualising the answers to some of the most frequently Googled questions. How long does it take to get to Mars? Why do cats purr? Or how much water should you drink a day. The internet is the first place that many people turn to for the answers, which takes a matter of seconds. But we tend to forget what we have learned just as quickly. It could be argued that we are becoming too reliant on internet search engines. Contrasting with instant online searches, these jigsaw puzzles require time and focus to explore the answers. ‘Life is Puzzling’ offers a rewarding and potentially social experience – you will definitely remember the outcome.

A museum shop that challenges exhibition etiquette, encouraging visitors to go their own way instead of trying to follow the unspoken rules. Many visitors of exhibitions have the same behavioural questions that they don’t dare to ask. Take, for example, Tristan Roques’ question #3: Can I start just anywhere?’. Or question #31: Should I tell everyone what my favourite is? And what about question #68: ‘How close should I stand to the work?’ His museum shop marks the beginning of your visit (rather than the usual end), with tools that propose silly but significant answers. Pick up a dice to decide where to start, or a moveable distance guide to determine your position. Worried about museum fatigue? Then bring a pillow tote bag to nap on.

This trophy-shaped sauce dispenser can be used to award everything, offering the appropriate words and symbols of praise, and a golden finishing touch. Tristan Roques challenges the value of the countless design prizes that are out there. Awards are like topping sauces, he says: they don’t improve what’s being awarded, but just make it look and taste better. So why not make this sauce available for everyone? Instead of having to enter an expensive competition, you can win one for free with ‘One More Award’. It presents the most frequently used adjectives and nouns from jury statements on brass plates; screw the preferred combination onto any object, finish it off with a splash of golden sauce, and let the ceremony begin.
