A video installation explores how the speed of digital technologies produce a desire to disconnect in order to reconnect with ourselves and the planet.

Maria’s is a mission to give voice to the multiple faces of Maria as a repressed and marginalized people through a multi-layered story of emancipation and political justice in Lima, Peru. The design in Maria’s is based on the thesis research of Mathematics of Resistance, which it in turn affects by adding new variables to its formulas. It focuses on improving Maria’s sidewalk through a network of solidarity and ownership that supports them, one already inherent to Lima, so that when they find themselves in situations of conflict they are not alone. A network of street vendors which has the ability to be as fluid and dynamic as the obstacles Maria faces and combines design with the human element to improve the urban language and create a new street-architecture by addressing four levels of need. The first is Maria’s primary needs of additional urban infrastructure, the second is the vendor’s need for legitimacy, the third is their mutual need for identity, and the fourth is addressing the conceptual ideologies discussed in Mathematics of Resistance. Furthermore, each of the vendors opens in a particular way that modifies the space they inhabit.

Powidoki focuses on the duality of the images which speak about the architecture and simultaneously speak about themselves. The project appreciates the role of the image and regards its nature as well as concentrate on the translation of space with respect to voice and character of place. An observational system consisting of 29 pinhole cameras was placed along the perimeter of the church’s interior, in an attempt to capture the space’s essence. Each camera with its specific placement represents the point of view of the wall. It lends its eye to the building and becomes part of its architecture. The collection of multiple viewpoints is composed into an „inverted panorama”, through which spectators gain insight into the dynamics of the place’s multilayered structure. In the same manner, the spectators are also confronted with a new type of gaze. They experience the perspective of the walls looking at each other, thus, they experience how the space might see itself. The camera listens to the voice of the building and through the image allows it to speak…

The car wash is one of the only interiors that is fully dedicated to machines. During this time the role of the human is passive, forced to wait for the pre programmed behaviour of the robots around them. Machine Wash Only gives us a glimpse of a world created by our domestic smart home devices. We have become subordinate to our devices becoming nothing more than objects producing data for our machines to learn from and evolve in our image. As a result we become machine – like following the preprogrammed smart home lifestyle where variety and spontenaity don’t exist. Machine Wash Only is a design object that decides for itself when it wants to be a table or when it wants to clean the floor shaping and defining our domestic interior and therefore how one should live.

Intrinsic to the city and complex, the sidewalk is an unavoidable part of daily urban life, a transient space of dynamism and conflict that comes into existence because of the interactions between the people who inhabit it, and is then dissolved as the users move on.  It is not a neutral space, but rather one of resistance and oppression. A place where what is a network of pathways and free space for some, is a collection of obstacles and obstructed space for others. Maria’s Sidewalk follows Maria’s experiences of the sidewalks of Miraflores, Lima, Peru. Maria, who is not one person, but the representation of the multiple identities of what I term the “other-woman”, that is, women who don’t fit any western social construct of woman. It is an attempt to understand, with their experiences and emotions, the DNA of the sidewalk.

The Other Room is a research project investigating speculative design in a series of suggestions for impossible interiors. For the group exhibition Loophole at Roodkapje Rotterdam, a detached movable wall (240*40*240cm) stands in the middle of the room. The mobile wall is decorated with an air vent suggestive of a building infrastructure and ducting system. A secondary vent is placed on a fixed structural wall in the gallery. Visitors could hear sounds coming through the vent. Voices of visitors chatting, familiar voices even alongside distant audio coming from the other projects. The two vents are connected in an invisible ducting system creating a one-way flow of communication, an unattainable inside, or an eavesdropping opportunity.

“A man of large purse has a very little soul which he keeps in it. The corruption of taste is a portion and a pendant of the dollar-manufacture. As we grow rich our ideas grow rusty. Now there is present to my mind’s eye a small and not ostentatious chamber with whose decorations no fault can be found.” The footage from the CCTV camera follows the novel named ‘The Philosophy of Furniture’ written by Edgar Allan Poe which illustrates the ideal room under capitalism. This collection of real-time worldwide chambers instills how monolithic the modern interior is, as a result of industrialization. The video was recorded at 14:50 on June 12, 2019.

As coping does not need to be rational, or does not necessitate dryness, Slumming At The Rodeo Gardens intermingle with theory & practice to propose a Resistance making room for the personal, the not-knowing & the crooked: dissolving the boundary between the political & the sensible. Composting mediums borrowed from the French bourgeoisie to transpose them into a interbred contemporary body of work, de Bréchard’s discourse argues for a critical visual pleasure via the messy & the confused.

titel: Link to VPN (Virtual PUB Network) in your Wi-Fi settings.
inhoud: VPN (Virtual PUB Network) is an eight node VPN (Virtual Private Network) installed physically at each exhibition venue during Sandberg Instituut’s graduation show. This virtual network explores the possibilities of autonomous infrastructures by building a zone of trust and situated knowledge opposing itself to the platformization of the institute. By building a local network and designing its architecture VPN aims to link all the distributed departments and generate space in between.

titel: Je krijgt van mij de hele dag (I’ll give you the entire day)
inhoud: Je krijgt van mij de hele dag presents a series of design interventions in the personal space of an inclusive care home in Rotterdam South. By creating work with residents, and incorporating their preferences and collective memory, Meeus creates objects and spaces with personal value. Reflecting a process of design from the inside, her work goes beyond raising awareness, to transform living conditions.

titel: 1. Without hope I have no dreams. 2. When did you become a heterosexual?
inhoud: Rowena takes you into their contrary worlds through different mediums. On the one hand an intimate family portrait. Rowena broke contact with their father, who has been struggling with an alcohol addiction, and does not have a stable place to live. When they heard that he found a home at a trailer park they thought it was time to contact him. On the other hand a project around sexuality, the heteronormative morals and some of the(in)visible aggressions that LGBTQ+ people have to face daily.

The work comprises a selection of designed objects—knick-knacks, trinkets, conversation pieces (if you will), decor (if you must)—that meditate upon (and dance around) the conceptual tension between opacity/transparency, contamination/purity, shit/value, commodity/fetish, surface/depth etc.

The documentary Aluminium Duce investigates the history of a fascist monument once located in Italy’s most northern region, South Tyrol. Andreas Trenker retraces the story of this statue from its blueprint to its destruction in 1961, exploring the violence performed by and against the effigy. By bringing together a variety of archival material and conducting interviews, the documentary functions as point of intersection of diametrically opposed views regarding the monument and and its meaning.

‘Untitled’ is an exploration of the systems of value, to which a creative practice owned by a non-EU citizen has to comply in order to remain in The Netherlands.  The perception of a non-EU creative as a single case and not as a part of a large group is facilitated by rhetorics and the ways in which the ‘terms and conditions’ are made impenetrable. The book documents working on an active approach to these ‘terms and conditions’.

titel: I wanted to like my work
inhoud: Working is not only about productivity anymore. Then what is the value of human labour? Working has been the centre of lifeworld. To explore the future, we need to investigate current position of work. For the discussion, I will depict the increasing job/phenomenon, Bull-Shit Jobs, that is defined by David Graeber.  In a waiting room, to get the fuel of current lifeworld(caffeine), participants will experience infrastructure of 'Bull-shit Jobs'.

Conspiratorial Mythologies is a three part project that looks back, into ancient Greek forms of storytelling, with the purpose of unveiling the truths hidden in conspiracy theories. What and who are we afraid of? Where will that fear take us?

Connecting the communities of the global supply chain. The global supply chain is designed for transporting goods, but can it be used as a platform for learning and empathy between communities around the globe? Supply Chain Broadcast is a digital audio visual station which shares the life and stories of communities along the chain with each other, uniting them in the knowledge of their individual contributions to production.

In the age of big data where digital surveillance is normalised in our everyday lives and tech corporations are taking over the administrative roles in our so-called smart cities. Who is being monitored and quantified, in which ways and for whose benefit? Can communities become resilient to structures of surveillance, reconnect with their territories and reclaim their data?

I've Been To Paradise' is an interactive narrative that explores euthanasia and end-of-life services through dialogue led gameplay. The game allows the player to role-play the last remaining days of a loved one's life, who has decided to perform euthanasia. The narrative takes place on a euthanasia cruise ship, a fictional platform to explore hypothetical and speculative approaches to the dying process within.

Climate Monsters.The Ecological Gaze.Developed with the community of Penablanca, a village in Chile experiencing rapid desertification, From Here We Go Extreme is an EP and music video that examines the collision of global and local imaginaries of climate change.
Ice Don't Drown is a video essay the investigates the Middle Passage's relationship with the Arctic through a series of interviews, music, and imagery.
A fake reveals inherent ideologies and questions what is regarded as “authentic”, “original” or “genuine”,  therefore a fake uncovers the precieved subjective validity and importance of an object.

titel: Psychic Medium Performs Exorcism On Visible Hand
inhoud: Psychic Medium Performs Exorcism On Visible Hand is a short allegorical horror film that addresses the economic-political driven housing crisis. Telling the story of a social housing building that has become possessed by the invisible hand of the free market.

titel: We are not the only kind of we
inhoud: For her work on ‘capitalist sorcery’, Merkel examined experience marketing as designed ritual to detect loopholes for ‘breaking the spell’. She developed site-specific choreographies for 12 performers, which act as collective body, appearing unsolicited to invade spaces for supervision. Interlinked with radio units, they move through illegible codes while whispering detailed descriptions. Sometimes individuals break free to reclaim personal agency only to fall back into the corporate ritual.

Diverse Fronts // Diverse Tactics explores how to mobilise people and utilise prefigurative methods in order to address social and economic injustices in society at large. How do you sustain interest in difficult topics?

Global Folk Television: Peek TV is a variety show format created in order to celebrate local communities and connect them with kindred spirits all over the world. The show’s central setting is a cartoon-vortex-clubhouse hosted by a friendly and sometimes confused human called John.

Phoniness' is an emerging method for projecting private discomfort and queer ambivalence onto public institutions, reshaping systems in a more pluralistic way. Connecting the dots between the 2020 U.S. Census and automatic grammar checkers, the project involves graphic and choreographic experiments in disrupting binaries.

As we grow numerous, resources grow more and more scares. Especially feeding all these people is becoming an growing problem and according to the FAO protein rich food will become scares in the near future. As a human and as a designer, I feel emerged in this problem. The future might not be so bright if we stick to our old ways. This made me research into the problem, hoping to understand it better and maybe find some possible answers. I am not a scientist, biologist or food expert, but i think that all outside of the box perspectives are to be overviewed. As a conclusion of my research, I found out that zooplankton is a rich source of protein that is not yet explored to itâ€™s full potential. We use it to feed our grown fish, but what about feeding it to us directly? As the numbers show this to be twice as efficient and way less time consuming to grow, I would like to start the conversation regarding the introduction of plankton, as a vital alternative in our protein diet. I welcome you all in my plankton research laboratory, where we discover the applications of zooplankton and would like to introduce you to menâ€™s new kind of cattle.

As a designer I am primarily a maker and I work from my great fascination for construction and material. By doing things manually and trying them out, my imagination gets going. The estranged effect on material and construction in an unusual context arouses my interest, because it makes me think. For example, mattresses that are discarded on the street and furniture that stands pathetic on the sidewalk immediately remind me of the intimacy of a lifetime. In my work I am looking for estrangement that makes you look better and I ask myself how by reviewing structures, I can give materials a different visual or constructive quality in order to get at a new visual language for my shoes. Craft making processes are great sources of inspiration for me to find gems of new form and technique details with which I can renew my visual language. With both product types, upholstered furniture as well as shoes, it is about a covering or upholster on a core construction: the furniture frame and the last. Both types of construction support
the covering. It starts with the frame itself, this is an important part to get to the shape and the part to which everything is attached. First a pattern is made on this, fabric is cut, then stitched together and fastened around the frame with nails. Filling or reinforcement may also be required. For my collection I use this world of upholstered furniture, I apply techniques such as padding, filling and folding in my shoe designs. I also use the â€œerrorsâ€ within the upholstery industry, such as upholstery over the old upholstery, for my shoes. I attach great importance to maintaining professional craftsmanship, because for me this is a source of inspiration for visual language innovation. I use exaggeration or magnification to give my shoe designs â€˜dramaâ€™ that can be strong and cheeky. For my shoes I opted for fabrics with a certain gloss such as satin, whereby shapes are accentuated by light and shadow. I have processed these fabrics by pressing them at a high temperature on a felt layer to create a higher quality and new appearance in the fabric. For the rougher side of my collection, the â€œbad habitâ€, I have mainly opted for somewhat matt fabrics such as denim and coarse cotton to achieve a rougher image due to the fraying that these woven fabrics entail.

With my collection Brave Hendrik I address the stereotypical image of man and offer a new freedom for male identity. At birth you are placed in the box of gender identity and based on this box the first choices are made for you, pink or blue, Cinderella or Superman, short or long hair. In short, gender identity determines which values and norms society sets for you. With my collection I want to move beyond this characterisation in society and invite people to be brave and to embrace the freedom to show as many sides of themselves as possible. I believe people can have a much more fluid character than merely being categorised as male or female. My designs allow people to explore who or what they can be, and this takes courage. All my designs are based on a 2D silhouettes, to then literally blow up this into a 3D form, this allows me to play with the transformation of 2D/3D. The sealing technique ensures an airtight shape and gives strength to the form. For the foot pieces I used patent leather, and used glue as a connection to make the airtight connection so the work gives shape. With the gloves it is human hand that creates volume and plays with form by wearing the pieces. The colours of my collection determine and evoke different associations. The shoulder pieces are made of a transparent PVC that creates an optical distortion of the body. In keeping with the change of form and the monumental nature of the head pieces. To emphasize the theatrical aspect of my accessories I use monumental forms. My accessories have distinct silhouettes and are intended as showpieces that can be used in dance performances, operas, performances, fashion shows or in the nightlife. Through my internship at RAVAGE, I had the opportunity to step into a world created by Clemens Rameckers and Arnold van Geuns. This inspired me to create my own world and progress with my thinking and design to work and provoke more with the changing stereotypes.

Our connection to the things around us has seemingly grown weaker. Throughout my study I have been experimenting with the notion of play within interior objects. By giving my designs a playful aspect, I want to strengthen the connection between user and the object. In the first place I hope to add some more joy to the static function of the furniture and other interior objects in our living rooms. Secondly, I strive to increase the time before we trade in our products for something new. My focus is to make the relation between use and function multi-interpretable, so that an object can easily be ascribed a different function or context. In this way my designs invite the user to be inventive and live with the work in new ways. With my graduation collection LUPA I designed a collection that brings playfulness into our interior, and thus into our daily lives. My designs have a flexibility; they have a playful and stubborn character, to evoke interaction. The starting point of my collection was a set of line drawings that I made while traveling. These drawings are born spontaneously from the shapes I see around me. They are the blueprints of my visual language. Scale variation is important, it gives direction to the function the object is being assigned. The line-drawings are my own landscape of forms. Creating such an own world of form and color as a starting point for my design process has become a way of working for me. My internship at Ontwerpduo inspired me to design products with the emphasis on accessibility. In the future, I aspire to further investigate the manufacturability of my products and gain more experience in this area.

Urban living space has proved to be an incredibly unstable commodity. Urbanisation causes living spaces to become increasingly smaller and less affordable. Trends such as micro-apartments and tower blocks show us a course of continual streamlining, systemising and micro-managing of living spaces and the cities surrounding them. This raises the question: Are our ideas on urban living space no longer viable? Given that these spaces are becoming less and less suitable for the activities they were originally intended for, one could question the precondition of owning our own living space. Room To Move showcases a scenario in which living spaces have been abrogated and fragmented into public structures. Being aware of an increasing amount of things being taken out of the living space nowadays, the project provides a superlative that challenges our existing preconditions. By focusing on sleep, one of the key activities within a living space, a system is visualised which facilitates sleep as a collective activity, instead of a private one. Due to the actuality and urgency of this phenomenon, we quickly became extremely interested and invested in this spatial problem and the ways we could approach it as designers. By developing a narrative as a basis for our project, we established a framework for ourselves in which we could explore and experiment with the various facets of our topic. A key element in our work is the returning use of the archetypical shape of a bed. Using this shape as a an icon for sleep, we visualise our scenario of collective sleeping. The result is a collection of works that visualise a radical and poetic approach, in order to break away from the rationality and hyper-efficiency which the topic is usually approached with. We are interested in the tension between the extreme and plausible, and want to use our work to showcase this.

I wish to explore the boundaries of imaginative design. To do so, the technique of drawing with a 3D pen is essential for this project. The futuristic scenario of directly visualising and producing a desired product â€“ in the single act of drawing â€“ represents the project rationale. For me, it is a magical way of bringing an idea to reality. The only design tool you need is the pure power of imagination and personalized drawing skills. If you want something, you draw it and it becomes a real product. Creating and producing by the means of drawing still seems to be a future fantasy, but for me itâ€™s all about dreaming big about this new opportunity. On the one hand, my shoe collection represents the expression of imagination. On the other hand, it reflects the applied form through material and technical experimentation. The research into visual and spatial implementation of the concept has a strong experimental character, due to the stimulation of new material properties and characteristics. The line-art is the 3D structure that shapes the shoe. At the same time they have a spatial network structure, in order to be able to meet the necessary load-bearing capacity of a shoe construction. My fascination for the skeleton as a supporting structure is reflected in my drawings. I have developed several drawing techniques that originate from skeleton structures. The ability to carry weight and at the same time be transparent, is the most important element of a skeleton. Different layers that remain visible one after the other. I consider the skin of the skeleton of a supportive feature, but also to emphasise the structure underneath it.

Land fishing is a plea to conscious handling of belongings and materials. As a designer I like to tell stories with images. My film and the objects I created combine to form the story of the land fisher. The live in a time in which cheap mass production encourages us to discard our belongings. We no longer become attached to our belongings as the possessions we have are easily replaceable, disposable and in our possession for a very short amount of time. This has lead to more waste. What we buy at online retailers is presented to us via customised algorithms, we search for unambiguous keywords in search engines for products. Surprises are hereby excluded. All kinds of things are washed up on our shores that were lost by chance or thrown away. Most people would consider these objects trash but beachcombers find value in such things. What they find they sell, even washed up wood. Other objects they find may be kept as souvenirs, like parts of sunken ships. Some things are reused and become parts of something new. The beachcomber allows himself to become surprised by what they might find washed ashore. I wish to expand on the mentality of the beachcomber and apply it to the behaviour of our consumer based society. Not only to the discarded belongings of beach goers. This behaviour can be observed everywhere people inhabit, even it cities. I want to encourage people to go land fishing. We need to rediscover the value of materials and objects that we have declared trash. Just for the pleasure of finding something and the game of searching.

The LAST DIVISION collection defines stereotyping in image about football players and their position. Also, it investigates technical research within last variety and application of the sole. A personal interest in football, its culture and individuality led to a footwear collection. In the world of football, a contrast exists between self- interest and acting as a team. With this in mind I created four characters and their bespoke footwear. The shoes represent recognizable characters within the 90 minutes of a game, but also their attitude outside of the pitch based on their position as well as their personality. This stereotyping is a sign of defining image, specialization and commercialization. The collection has been created by developing a technique of making lasts. The last is a very defining mold for the final shape and characteristics of a shoe. However, due to the system of the industry of footwear, lasts are not easy accessible for a designer to obtain and use in small range. To get around these restrictions I found a method to assemble and vary with the molds differently. The segmentation of a last provides a way to create every modeled shape, offering me the possibility to specialize the last on each imago and character. LAST DIVISION embodies the analyzing image maker as well as a rather technical developer in me. The built characters are divided into parameters, always starting with the base of the last and the way it is segmented. To complete the personalities the further image is created by adjusting material, sole, studs, closing and position of the player.

I want to tell a story: about actively living with objects; About habits and habitat; And about our framed view. We tend to do things out of habit, like weâ€™ve always done. Do we ever question them? I like to question everything: â€œHow do we live with objects? What are the boundaries of the concept of a carpet? Why donâ€™t we put mirrors on the floor? And if Cinderellaâ€™s shoe fit perfectly, then why did it fall off?â€. Weâ€™ve framed reality. It makes the world structured and clear. We need frames, but they can also hold us back. To reframe â€“ to step back from what is being said and consider the frame through which reality is being created â€“ considers alternative perspectives. Reframing opens up new ways of seeing, thinking and acting. I want to reframe life. I started at home. Home is the place where we live. I see living not as passively being surrounded by objects, but as an active usage of the objects we surround ourselves with. Our home objects are the props of our existence and our home is a decor where our daily life unfolds. My collection of home objects offer a new perspective on daily life and our home. My carpet gives you a new perspective of a place you may know so well. Mirroring and expanding the space it lies in and deforming it when interacted with. My clothing hangers give you a new perspective of the clothes you wear daily. By hanging them on the wall, the clothing transforms into an artwork that is literally framed. It lets you focus on the stitches and form details of something often so close to you that you may not notice it anymore. Moving from the space we live in, to the material we live with, to the body itself: I framed the foot. The slippers in my collection give the foot a new perspective. While the rectangular shape of the sole ignores the form of the foot, the woven elastics embraces the form when worn. With my collection I want to put daily life in a different perspective and stimulate a mentality that questions the ordinary and doesnâ€™t settle for things that â€˜has always been that way.â€™. The way that I question the boundaries of objects, I also question the boundary of my own discipline. I work on the intersection of product, graphic and research design with a passion for philosophy and the ordinary.

Every day we go to work, every day we prepare a meal to eat around six and every day we ask the same question; how are you? Nowadays more often people will answer with â€˜itâ€™s busy!â€™ and this is perceived as something positive, but is it a always a good thing? We want to fit into society so we adapt to the existing rhythm that we have created. Sometimes it seems that we forget how unique we as individuals are and that everyone has their own pace. Do we listen enough to ourselves or is the collective rhythm too overpowering? With my graduation project TAKT, I want to approach our hectic pace of life in a contemplative way in order to stimulate a conversation with the viewer. Questioning whether it can be different. The need to create a different rhythm of life is becoming ever greater. Also from the fact that not everyone can cope with the current fast pace of life. The pressure to be a part of this hectic life is building up. People are increasingly looking for a solution to reach their full potential and to keep up with this lifestyle. Many young people experience the fierce competition and the high expectations set by our modern society. With my ceramic objects, I want to physically represent the different rhythms of life and hence start a discussion about this lack of time and the need for a more individual pace. The objects in the collection all have a different way of moving. One moves much faster than the other, however together they reinforce each other. With my objects I want to emphasize the beauty of these differences and appreciate the uniqueness of every rhythm on its own and together as a collection.

As a designer I want to respond to current problems I find in news articles. I look for solutions to problems that involve functionality and a clear, simple form- language that is created through simple interventions. In recent years I have focused my research on natural resources that can be used as a sustainable material. Environmental issues and climate awareness play an important role in the process. Currently, many people live in an unhealthy environment due to the presence of particulate matter and toxic gases in the air. The purification of the ambient air is of great importance, especially for asthma patients, people with COPD and with skin problems. This can be achieved in a natural way by using the purifying property of salt. My collection illustrates how this can be translated into the home environment. I have researched techniques of salt evaporation and its properties on all my products. Salt crystals grow out of salt solution. In dry form they also have an air purifying effect. The collection consists out of a humidifier, a radiator, a lamp and mouth caps. The humidifier consists of a reservoir filled with saltwater and a timer that regulates the evaporation mechanism. The lamp was made in collaboration with Mika Tsutai, from the Kyoto Institute of Technology. The lampshade is made from the material Mika brought from Japan. The material consists of a paper fiber and natural glue which is combined with salt crystals. The lampshade is heated by the lamp and could, if possible, emit negative ions, a principle based on the operation of the Himalayan salt-lamps. I applied the same principle to a radiator. The outside of the radiator is covered with a layer of salt and due to the heat of the water that flows through the pipes the salt could emit negative ions. The salt on the mouth caps is crystallized in the substance by capillary action and is released by the condensation produced from breath. With this project I wanted to investigate the meaning of design in health care, and I want to discuss the possibility of supportive treatments supplementary to conventional healthcare.

Objects for a cashless society is a collection of fictional products that respond to the digitization of money. The financial world is becoming increasingly complex. Coins and bills are replaced by alternative money flows and intangible value systems. Social and emotional aspects getting lost. Technological developments are increasingly moving towards a frictionless transition between the analogue and digital world. But what are the side effects of these developments? How will this â€˜digitalâ€™ world look like? What are the consequences of the loss of physical money? Imagine how the following scenarios will take place; A child who received his pocket money, rewarding a street musician for his performance, making a wish in a fountain or filling a piggy bank. I want to show alternatives to these technological developments. With this collection, I want to make a complex system tangible again, showcasing the human side, stepping away from a society that consequences the loss of human interaction. And itâ€™s no surprise, given that so many people accumulate credit card debt, that people tend to be less financially responsible when paying in the abstract.

As a free-thinker and a designer I create stories that move. I comment on entrenched social ideas and assumptions by playing with the way we look at things. I stretch up the meaning of objects, break with habits and exaggerate the expectations we have of objects through physical and philosophical research. For my graduation project I was inspired by the Dada movement. I relate to their independent attitude towards social practices. Marina AbramovicÌ§ and Pussy Riot are also inspiring to me. They break with conventional assumptions through total commitment and dedication to their subject. That is how they ensoul their work. The chair is the central subject and object of my graduation. A chair is an archetypical object within the design landscape. To me, it also functions as storyteller of the relationship we have with objects. I started my research with physical experiments: I asked the chair to dance. Chairs are made to carry the human body and are shaped around it, but they also resemble humans in themselves. They have legs and a torso. Next to my physical experiments with chairs, I researched the way people use chairs in daily life. It struck me that chairs sometimes have an important reflecting role to humans. For example, at weddings people sometimes place a nameplate on a chair, which represents a person that has recently passed away. The chair is also an element of play. In Japan, the office chair Grand Prix race is organized. Office chairs are used as vehicles to race against each other. During the race it is not allowed to get off your seat. The Grand Prix came into existence during the long days that people spend in the office. My research resulted in the development of six different danceable chairs that come to life through film and performance. I work with chairs I found on the street. I adopted the chairs and enlarged their motion and character. The film in which I show a dance with chairs, creates a world in which they are my partner. With my project I strive to liberate the chair of its proposed function by playing with expectations. I hope to inspire people to look behind given borders. To see how we can adopt a different attitude towards objects like the chair. I firmly belief that objects reflect the way we treat them. If we keep an open mind, we can build long-term relationships with them, in which reciprocity exists between the object and its user.
